executive_summary: Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2024 currency. Boat builders manufacture various watercraft intended for personal, commercial and government use. These products are highly discretionary purchases, so boat builders benefit from growing consumer confidence, disposable income and spending. Poor performance during the pandemic and due to high interest rates have bracketed otherwise torrid expansion from boat builders. Overall, revenue has expanded at an expected CAGR of 2.7% to $14.6 billion through the current period, including a 1.8% jump in 2024, where profit will reach 5.1%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Volatile economic conditions have hindered growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Economic uncertainty caused by the pandemic and skyrocketing interest rates has bracketed strong growth for boat builders. Notably, consumer confidence plummeted in 2020, discouraging consumers from purchasing boats.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Many consumers purchased boats during the pandemic
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Lockdown restrictions amid the pandemic led to shifting leisure and entertainment consumption trends. Private boating activities represented an outlet for many individuals seeking safe, outdoor activities.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Supply chain volatility limits profit growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Boat builders have faced volatile global and domestic supply chains following the pandemic and the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Climbing crude oil prices contributed to a wide range of commodity price increases.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Boat builders have faced unfavorable trade markets
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The appreciation of the US dollar has posed a major threat to domestic boat builders, especially in more standardized boat and parts markets. Domestic boat builders have endured skyrocketing imports and historic import penetration.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Boat builders will continue to bolster sales by offering packages tailored to individual consumer needs, leading to higher demand for custom-built boats. Boat builders can offer a wide range of customizations based on consumer preferences.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Technological innovation will support profit growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Many boat builders have adopted new technology to improve internal efficiency and appeal to buyers. Most builders have adopted internal automation to eliminate assembly positions and save on wage expenses.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Economic stability will create new opportunities
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Improving economic conditions will support an influx of demand for new boats and boat rentals, supporting demand for consumer and commercial markets. In particular, normalizing interest rates will encourage consumers to take out loans and invest in new boats.
Greater per capita disposable income coupled with pent-up demand for travel following lockdown restrictions will create new opportunities for boat builders, especially in commercial markets.

industry_definition: Manufacturers in this industry build boats, defined as watercraft not built in shipyards, intended for personal, commercial and government use. This industry does not include shipbuilding (IBISWorld report 33661a).
key_trends: Competition is on the rise. Consolidation among boat builders will grow as larger producers attempt to improve their market share and expand into new, more lucrative markets.
Economies of scale are vital for success. Research and development into streamlined production will be crucial for boat builders seeking to stand out.
Rising inflation has stymied boat-building demand. As a highly discretionary purchase, skyrocketing interest rates have discouraged buyers from taking out loans to purchase boats.

Boat builders will benefit from strong economic growth through the outlook period. Rising employment and per capita disposable income will translate to increased demand. Prospective customers will continue to gravitate towards custom products.
Brunswick remains the sole major player. Brunswick has increased its market share concentration through strategic acquisitions and research and development.
Smaller companies make up the majority of the boat-building industry. Companies often prioritize specific niches, leading to notable market fragmentation and varied market saturations.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Households for personal and leisure use generate the largest revenue for boat builders.
Commercial markets commonly include leisure and fishing operations, like charter boats, liveaboard vacations and smaller-scale commercial fishing.
Multiple military branches and public sector buyers purchase boats and parts for operation.

products_and_services.product_description: An outboard motorboat is a small to medium-size boat powered by a self-contained detachable engine and propulsion system attached to the transom. This category includes runabouts, bass boats, utility boats and offshore fishing boats.
Inboard motorboats are mid-sized boats powered by an attached engine located inside the hull, normally in the middle or front of the boat, with a prop shaft running through the bottom of the boat.

Boat parts and repair services are the smallest product segment. Modern boats make use of many mechanical parts and require regular servicing. Also, personalized watercraft often require specialized maintenance.

tier_1_suppliers: Navigational Instrument Manufacturing in the US
Wind Turbine Manufacturing in the US
Engine & Turbine Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Rubber Product Manufacturing in the US
Glass Product Manufacturing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Boat Dealership and Repair in the US
tier_2_buyers: Ocean & Coastal Transportation in the US
Inland Water Transportation in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Demand for boat building closely relates to overall economic growth. In particular, higher discretionary income levels encourage boat purchases from consumer and commercial markets. Rebounding per capita disposable income has presented new opportunities for domestic boat builders.

Boats are expensive purchases; lower-income buyers commonly struggle to afford new boats, payment loans and associated upkeep and fuel costs, making households earning more than $100,000 the industry's primary market. In general, the economy's highest earners make up the majority of boat buyers.

As a measure of people's attitudes toward spending, the Consumer Confidence Index indicates spending habits on superfluous and luxury goods, including boats. Higher consumer confidence suggests greater consumer willingness to purchase luxury goods.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Imports' share of domestic demand has been volatile, demonstrated by imports significantly falling in 2020 as COVID-19 reduced demand for boats. Still, the value of imports has increased, and importers have benefited from an appreciating US dollar.

Italy has been the largest source of imports, followed by Italy, France, the United Kingdom and Taiwan. European nations have some of the largest boat producers in the world and are known for their luxury boats.
The value of exports increased due to an appreciating US dollar, which led to exports being more expensive and hurting domestic producers' price competitiveness.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Exports Popular in Americas and Tourist Destinations
international_trade_points.trade_description: Exports are most popular in Canada and Mexico, though Spain and Italy are major importers of domestic boat goods as well. As major tourist destinations famous for their coastal attractions, these four countries will continue to be major export destinations.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast is home to the largest number of boat building facilities, with North Carolina accounting for many establishments in the region.
The West is the second-largest region in terms of business locations. Washington has a rapidly growing boat building industry and is already home to many boat builders.
New England leads the remainder of the country in boat building; Maine hosts the region's largest share of locations due to the state's high level of fishing and lobstering activity.
The Great Lakes region is home to some establishments due to their vicinity to large bodies of water.
The Mid-Atlantic region is home to some establishments due to their vicinity to large bodies of water.
The Plains region doesn't produce boating goods since shipping to larger bodies of water is costly and too detrimental to revenue.
The Southwest region doesn't produce boating goods since shipping to larger bodies of water is costly and too detrimental to revenue.
The Rocky Mountains region doesn't produce boating goods since shipping to larger bodies of water is costly and too detrimental to revenue.

regulations_points.regulation_title: US Coast Guard and Federal Legislation
regulations_points.regulation_description: The US Coast Guard is given the authority under federal statute law, specifically title 46, to manage recreational boat manufacturing. Legislation under both regulatory bodies covers the design and construction of recreational boats and includes manufacturer certification, boat identification, capacity information display, safe loading, safe powering, flotation, electrical systems, fuel systems, ventilation, start-in-gear protection, navigation lights and back-fire flame control.
Manufacturers follow workplace and safety regulations set by the Occupational Health and Safety Administration (OSHA) alongside state and local regulatory bodies.
Companies must negotiate union standards and requests, especially regarding pay and safety.

Facilities are subject to extensive environmental legislation concerning waste management, air emissions, toxic use reduction and environmental cleanup, among others and are required to comply with other environmental laws and regulations.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The boat building industry is mature.
The industry experiences high revenue volatility.

basis_points.basis_description: Consolidation among boat builders will grow as larger producers attempt to improve their market share and expand into new, more profitable segments.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Most domestic boat builders are small and independently owned. Companies only operate one or a few facilities, resulting in low market share concentration.
Market concentration increased as consolidation persisted. For example, Brunswick acquired Garelick Manufacturing, a Minnesota-based manufacturer of marine products.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Market share concentration will grow slowly but steadily
concentration_points.concentration_description: Market share concentration is expected to remain steady through the end of 2028. Mergers and acquisitions and high revenue will remain a key growth strategy.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Boat Builders Have High Wage Expenses
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages represent the second-largest expense; boat building is highly labor-intensive, requiring skilled labor, like engineers, for research and development, design and quantity control positions.
Commercial and governmental contracts often require bulk production. Boat builders have focused on streamlining production to capitalize on economy of scale.

Increased demand for made-to-order boats has driven front-end innovations within boat building. Boat builders have added more advanced navigation systems and better onboard amenities to attract customers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: BOAT BUILDERS HAVE FACED INPUT VOLATILITY
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Boat builders have endured volatile input costs following the pandemic and the Russian invasion of Ukraine. In particular, steel, aluminum and plastic material prices spiked in 2021, contributing to profit declines.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: For custom builders catering to high-end markets, skilled labor is vital and acts as barriers to entry. Boat builders entering the mass production segment must overcome high initial capital costs when purchasing the required machinery, equipment and technology.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Boat builders primarily rely on consumer and commercial markets; positive economic conditions and consumer markets often encourage people to spend more on travel and luxury items, like boats.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Boat builders have focused on streamlining production to capitalize on economy of scale. Builders have tried a variety of methods, to varying degrees of success, to cut down production time and per-unit material costs.

Increased demand for made-to-order boats has driven front-end innovations within boat building. Boat builders have added more advanced navigation systems and better onboard amenities to attract customers.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: The health of the US economy is vital. Consumers will purchase boats as economic conditions improve.

FAQs.question: Have export markets offered an opportunity for your company?
FAQs.answer: The European and Canadian markets account for the majority of exports. Companies primarily target wealthy export markets and travel destinations.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing heavily in R&D to meet changing consumer preferences?
FAQs.answer: R&D investment has been crucial for manufacturers to stay at the forefront of consumer demand for more fuel-efficient vessels.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Volatile input prices pose a major threat to sustainable profit growth. Companies often maintain long-term supply contracts to mitigate volatility.

FAQs.question: What steps does your company take to ensure that it is safeguarding proprietary information?
FAQs.answer: Enforcing intellectual property (IP) regulations is critical to protecting and/or leveraging a company's competitive edge.

FAQs.question: How does your company invest in technology to establish a competitive edge over your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Technology - Incorporating technology from outside the industry, like 3D printing, can reduce manufacturing expenses. - Technology is increasingly penetrating the manufacturing sector, increasing efficiency and bolstering profitability.

FAQs.question: Is your company adequately prepared to adjust to changing environmental standards?
FAQs.answer: Compliance - Noncompliance with regulatory controls like environmental laws can carry heavy penalties, including revocation of permits, corrective action orders, administrative or civil penalties and criminal prosecution.

FAQs.question: How have international tariffs affected your ability to import and export products?
FAQs.answer: Compliance - European and Canadian tariffs can threaten exports, while US tariffs on aluminum are increasing purchase costs. - In 2019, trade tensions with China and the subsequent steel tariffs, among many others, led to increasing input costs. Continued tariffs pose a long-term threat.

FAQs.question: What is your company doing to improve profit margins?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers have consolidated and restructured operations to improve efficiency and profit.

FAQs.question: How does your company compensate for seasonality of cash flow?
FAQs.answer: Cash flow in this industry is somewhat seasonal, with sales strongest in summer months.

FAQs.question: How much do you spend annually on research and development? How do you differentiate yourself from your competition?
FAQs.answer: Undertaking technical research and development Boat builders that target high-end clientele increasingly use innovative inputs to differentiate from competitors and charge a price premium. Companies have created value-added products, like GPS and sonar, to appeal to specific functions.

FAQs.question: How do you ensure that you have a strong financial structure? What are your key financial drivers? How well capitalized are you?
FAQs.answer: Financial structure of the company Due to the long lead times in the design, construction and delivery of boats, manufacturers must have a strong financial structure. Boat building can often have long lead times, given the lengthy nature of the building process.

FAQs.question: How do you ensure you have access to the latest technology? Do competitors have access to any technology you do not?
FAQs.answer: Access to the latest available and most efficient technology and techniques Boat building requires manufacturers to be well-informed about the latest technological advances and technical and performance characteristics.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the Consumer Confidence Index? How can you adapt as the Consumer Confidence Index declines?
FAQs.answer: Since boats are discretionary purchases and expensive to own, consumers only purchase them when they believe that economic conditions are favorable.

FAQs.question: Do you target wealthy consumers and business clients?
FAQs.answer: Households earning more than $100,000 Since recreational boats are considered luxury goods, wealthier consumers more commonly purchase pleasure craft. These groups are also more recession-resistant and are more likely to purchase boats.

FAQs.question: Do you track consumer spending? Can your growth rates exceed increases in consumer spending?
FAQs.answer: Per capita disposable income Boats are expensive discretionary purchases. As a result, demand depends on disposable income levels. Consumers have more money to spend on boats when per capita disposable income rises.
